explanation:
- statvfs: The controlling expression is statvfs(local->system_mountpt, &stat_buf) != 0. You must see the definition/declaration of statvfs to know whether it is an actual runtime function call (non‑constant) or a macro/inline that could expand to an invariant expression.
- struct statvfs (definition): Needed to confirm the types of the arguments/return and whether any compile‑time constant folding could occur via its fields or via statvfs semantics.
- OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET (macro): This macro produces the local pointer used to obtain local->system_mountpt. If this macro expands to something that affects the call (e.g. inlining, constant), it can change whether the controlling expression can be evaluated as invariant.
- OS_filesys_internal_record_t (definition): Required to know the type and semantics of the system_mountpt field (its type, constness, possible macros) which is passed to statvfs; this influences whether the argument is a compile‑time constant.
- OS_filesys_table (object): If OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET uses this global table to produce a compile‑time constant pointer or mounts, that could make the statvfs call behave deterministically at compile time in some build configurations.
- OS_object_token_t (type/definition): OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET is invoked with *token; the token type or its dereference operator/macros could expand to a constant index affecting the obtained local pointer.
- OS_ObjectIndexFromToken: The static call graph shows many callers use this; if OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET expands to or uses OS_ObjectIndexFromToken, its implementation (macro vs function, side effects) must be inspected to determine if the object lookup is a runtime operation or a constant, which bears on whether the controlling expression can be invariant.
